AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Explosively crisp and juicy! Cold hardy and disease resistant.

Alternate 2-3½" long and 1¼-2¼" across, occur along the twigs and young shoots. The leaf blades are lanceolate-ovate to ovate and finely serrated or crenulated along margins. The upper surface of the leaf blades is yellowish green to dark green and hairless, pale gray green or whitish and downylower surface.
Gray brown to pale purple-brown, scaly. With age develops thin, peeling flakes.
1-1 1/2" wide, showy; white tinged with pink. Five rounded petals. Each flower on long stalk in small clusters. Fragrant.

Cold hardiness and high fruit quality. Explosively crisp, juicy texture. Medium to large. 2-3/4" to 4" (7.0-10.2 cm). Oblate to round oblate. 60-90 percent dappled red over yellow in cool climates. May not color as well in warmer climates. Explosively crisp! Coarse texture. Light and very juicy. Well-balanced: sweet-tart. May be mild in warmer climates if harvested early or if trees are heavily cropped.

The Honeycrisp apple was first sold in stores in 1997 and was developed by the University of Minnesota. since then it has exploded in popularity and has become one of the most grown apples in America. The Honeycrisp is exceptionally crisp and juicy, has amazing color, can be stored for a long time, is very cold hardy, and is fairly disease resistance. All of these attributes have made it an all-time favorite here in Minnesota and it can be found in orchards and backyards alike. This perfect texture and taste lend itself up for baking or for enjoying as a health snack all on its own.
* The Honeycrisp Apple planted on the northwest corner of Phelps Hall is a memorial tree dedicated by Steve Morrison in memory of Diane Morrison.
